info.title: Delivery REST API
info.description: The Delivery API is a read-only REST API that serves published content from your Kontent.ai projects.

tags.name: SDKs
tags.description:
We offer the following SDKs to help you interact with the API. However, you don't need an SDK to use the API.

* [JavaScript/TypeScript SDK](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/552424ff-28ed-4668-86eb-55400da43d87)
* [.NET SDK](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/fc2b0841-46c3-4fb4-9aa5-ea771b6fb221)
* [Java SDK](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/584073a7-9783-4311-9893-d2a1c61cb025)
* [PHP SDK](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/a986a04a-3afa-410b-b933-d1d3e6e87e15)
* [Swift SDK](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/9af70b2e-e015-40b1-9f31-38f7b2960de8)
* [Ruby SDK](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/2c242462-d1eb-44ab-b3f9-049dfa335d6a)

If you want to create your own SDK, see our [guidelines for SDK developers](https://github.com/Kentico/Home/wiki/Guidelines-for-SDK-developers "Guidelines for SDK developers").

tags.name: API limitations
tags.description:
## API requests limit

Requests made to the Delivery API count towards the overall _API Calls_ limit set in our [Fair Use Policy](https://kontent.ai/pricing/fup).

Requests made to the [Delivery Preview API](#section/Production-vs.-Preview), which lets you preview unpublished content, do NOT count towards the _API Calls_ limit.

## Change processing time

The Delivery API processes changes to your content items in sequential order, one after another. In high-volume scenarios, this can lead to delays between making a change and seeing the results of that change in the API. See the following example scenarios for details.

**Example A: Editing and publishing content items**

If you publish a content item, the API processes this change in a few seconds. When publishing larger amounts of content, there can be a delay in availability of that content in the API.

For example, if you publish 100 content items, the first item will be available a few minutes sooner than the last one.

**Example B: Editing content types**

When you change a content type, the API needs to process all content items based on that type. If your changes affect hundreds or thousands of content items, the API recalculates the content of each item. While this is happening, any new changes to content items need to wait before being processed by the API.

For example, imagine you have an _Article_ content type with 100,000 content items based on that type. If you add an element to the content type, the API goes through the items and begins updating their content. Given the high number of items, this process can take up to a few hours.

Until the API finishes processing the _Article_ items, any subsequent content changes need to wait. If you publish a content item right after modifying the _Article_ content type, the published item appears in the API only after the type change was fully processed.

**Example C: Changing project localization settings**

We strongly recommend against changing language codenames on live projects with lots of content. This action might lead to temporary inconsistencies that might affect content in your web app.

If you change a [project language](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/9e0f560c-5ee4-4649-818a-c5f934b82f4a)'s codename, the API needs to process all items that have content in that language. Until this change is fully processed, the API might return some items with the old language codename and some items with the new language codename.

## Rate limitation

Rate limits specify the number of requests you can make to the Delivery API within a specific time window.

Your first request to the Delivery API is uncached and its response is stored in our CDN. If you repeat that request, you get a cached response. That response is cached until content in your project changes.

For uncached requests that reach the Delivery API, we enforce a rate limitation of 100 requests per second and 2000 requests per minute. These are unique requests for uncached data.

For cached requests that hit our CDN, we don't enforce any rate limits. These are repeated requests for cached data. You can make an unlimited number of requests to the CDN.

When you reach the rate limit, the API rejects the request and responds with a [429 HTTP error](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/429 "Too Many Requests"). This error comes with the [`Retry-After` header](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Retry-After) that tells you how many seconds you need to wait before retrying your request. Each failed request is perfectly safe to retry. If you begin to receive 429 errors, reduce the frequency of your requests.

## Response size

When you [request a single content item](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/419ae032-ad24-4990-89a7-2f13ba7c9beb) or [list of items](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/4fafdf10-32c6-4020-a91a-cf1f835f8107), the Delivery API limits the maximum number of items returned within a response to 2000 items. This number covers both the items that directly match the specified query and the [linked items](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/286dbb0e-f673-494f-abfd-3f39c7ec3446) returned in the response's `modular_content` property.

You can find whether your requests are close to the limit by looking at the `X-Request-Charge` header.

If the `X-Request-Charge` value of your requests exceeds 1000, we recommend applying more specific [filters](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/b6cf1d73-471a-4f1e-b0a9-f0e041e2d905) and checking if a lower value for the [`depth` parameter](#tag/Linked-content-and-components/linked-content-depth) works for you. Fewer items returned per response means shorter response times and better performance for your app.

tags.name: Secure access
tags.description:
By default, the Delivery API does not require authentication. This means your assets and published content items are publicly available.

You can enable secure access for your project to require authenticated requests. You'll then need to use an API key when getting content items.

Because the Delivery API is designed for continuous retrieval of published content, there is **no expiration date** for the Primary or Secondary API keys. The API keys are **scoped per project**. This means you need a separate API key for each project in Kontent.ai. All users within a single project share the same Delivery API keys.

If you have [advanced asset management](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/2123ff88-1dc2-476c-b9bd-877821fe0110), you can also set up secure assets for your project. For more details, check how to [restrict public access](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/961f2179-e62c-4927-a7ad-e270d55fb61f).

tags.name: Revoking API keys
tags.description:
The Delivery API with [secure access](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/312ecd2f-d37f-4055-82c2-ac912d0d4b8d) enabled and the Delivery Preview API both use two concurrent API keys, Primary and Secondary. In certain situations, you may need to revoke one of these keys and generate a new one. For example, when you suspect unauthorized key use or when a developer with access to the API key has left your company. For situations like these, one or both of the API keys can be regenerated. Generating a new key will replace the old key. This process can take up to a couple of minutes. Requests made with a revoked API key will then receive a `401 Unauthorized` HTTP status in the response.
**Keep your API keys secure** There is no expiration date for the Primary or Secondary API key. However, we recommend that you regenerate the API keys periodically to prevent the keys from being compromised. Learn more in Securing public access and Configuring content preview.

tags.name: Errors
tags.description:
<SchemaDefinition schemaRef="#/components/schemas/error_object" showReadOnly={true} showWriteOnly={true} showExample={true}/> 

If you cannot identify and resolve an issue with your API call, you can contact us with the response status and the request ID you get in the error response.

tags.name: Content items
tags.description:
Content items represent specific pieces of content based on a specific content type. To retrieve specific items from your project, either [provide a codename for one item](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/419ae032-ad24-4990-89a7-2f13ba7c9beb) or [filter all items using parameters](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/b6cf1d73-471a-4f1e-b0a9-f0e041e2d905). By default, the Delivery API returns content items in the [default language](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/9e0f560c-5ee4-4649-818a-c5f934b82f4a).

## Content item object

<SchemaDefinition schemaRef="#/components/schemas/content_item" showReadOnly={true} showWriteOnly={true} showExample={true}/>

tags.name: Content elements
tags.description:
When getting [content items](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/0768ece4-91da-42a4-bab0-2086c66f9953) or [content types](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/6eec4ee8-1e14-433c-b35b-39e9d151a377), you get the `elements` object property as a part of the retrieved item or type. Each element in `elements` contains the properties `type`, `name`, and `value`. Note that certain elements, such as [rich text](#section/Rich-text-element) or [taxonomy](#section/Taxonomy-element), can contain additional properties. ## Asset element ## Content type snippet element The Content type snippet elements are expanded into the elements that they contain. You can recognize the expanded elements by their codenames, which use the following format: `__`. For example, when you [retrieve an item](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/419ae032-ad24-4990-89a7-2f13ba7c9beb) that uses a snippet element with 2 elements, the snippet itself will be structured as the 2 elements, without any encapsulation. ```json "seo_metatata__meta_keywords": { "type": "text", "name": "Meta keywords", "value": "donation, africa" }, "seo_metatata__meta_description": { "type": "text", "name": "Meta description", "value": "Regularly donate money." } ``` ## Custom element [Create your own custom element](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/70496a22-6c7a-4c15-ab88-b70b9f3d24f1) or discover existing ones in the [Custom element sample gallery](https://kentico.github.io/kontent-custom-element-samples/gallery/ "Custom element sample gallery"). ## Date and time element ## Linked items element ## Multiple choice element ## Number element ## Rich text element In addition to formatted text, the rich text element's `value` property can contain objects representing images, components, content items. Information about these objects is stored in separate properties: * `images` – stores metadata of assets in the text. * `links` – stores metadata about content items linked in the text. * `modular_content` – stores metadata of linked items and components in the text. ### Images (single object) The images in the rich text's `value` are represented by the `figure` and `img` HTML tags. ```html ``` ### Links (single object) The links in the rich text's `value` are represented by the `a` HTML tags. ```html link to a content item link to web URL mailto link link to asset ``` ### Modular content (components and items in rich text) The content items and components inserted in the rich text's `value` are represented by the `object` HTML element. For both content items and components, the `object` HTML element specifies these attributes: * `data-type` – Its value is `item` for both content items and components. This lets you use a single method to resolve your items and components. * `data-rel` – Its value is either `link` (for content items inserted into rich text) or `component` (for components inserted into rich text). Use the attribute to differentiate between components and items. * `data-codename` – Its value specifies the codename of the content item or component.
**Two distinct** `modular_content` **properties** In the `modular_content` object property of the Delivery API response, you can find the contents of the linked content items and content components. In the rich text element's [modular_content array property](#section/Rich-text-element/modular-content-components-and-items-in-rich-text), you can find the codenames of the inserted content items and content components. The codenames in the rich text's `modular_content` array are grouped and ordered. First comes a group of item codenames followed by a group of component codenames. The order of codenames in each group matches that in the UI.
```html ``` ## Subpages element This element works only with [Web Spotlight](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/fd0a51f1-703e-4eba-9882-5874d3ab61f3) enabled. ## Taxonomy element ## Text element ## URL slug element

tags.name: Content types
tags.description:
Content types define the structure of [content items](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/0768ece4-91da-42a4-bab0-2086c66f9953). Each content type consists of specific [content elements](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/ea9768d1-bd2f-4027-bb5e-5cd9c85ea360) that define what kind of content (i.e., which data types) the structure holds.

## Content type object

<SchemaDefinition schemaRef="#/components/schemas/content_type" showReadOnly={true} showWriteOnly={true} showExample={true}/>

tags.name: Languages
tags.description:
Languages let you create multilingual content. If you've [set up languages](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/9e0f560c-5ee4-4649-818a-c5f934b82f4a) for your project, you can [get localized content](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/bf83b286-9972-4e65-8db9-412ca17df944) for each content item by using the `language` query parameter. You can also [get languages](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/f72e9ef6-cfc8-4afd-9594-ec3182f74b4a) from your project to dynamically create a language selector in your app, for example.
**Use short machine-readable codenames** We strongly recommend that you use short, easily identifiable, and machine-readable codenames for your languages. For example, you can specify language codenames based on the [IETF or one of the ISO-639 standards](https://web.archive.org/web/20210613212458/https://www.venea.net/web/culture%5Fcode).
## Language object

tags.name: Taxonomy groups
tags.description:
Taxonomies are a versatile tool for categorizing and organizing your content.

Learn more about the [use cases for taxonomies](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/6a031f62-f076-4477-8b80-2e75115e9f32) and see how to [retrieve content tagged with a specific taxonomy term](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/c5772d90-44e8-4120-9d1c-515f20197759).

## Taxonomy group object

<SchemaDefinition schemaRef="#/components/schemas/taxonomy_group" showReadOnly={true} showWriteOnly={true} showExample={true}/>

tags.name: Filtering content
tags.description:
When [getting content items](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/4fafdf10-32c6-4020-a91a-cf1f835f8107), you can filter your items by building query parameters from content elements and system properties. Check our [tutorial on filtering content items](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/c5772d90-44e8-4120-9d1c-515f20197759), which covers the basic use of common filtering parameters. Or read on for a deep dive.
Filtering does not apply to content items returned in the `modular_content` object property.
If you want to get only a specific set of elements from content items, use [projection](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/c4552a2f-142c-4415-b7aa-f2c5b165a84e). ### Filtering by system values To filter by system property values, you need to use a query parameter in the `system.` format. The system properties are `id`, `collection`, `name`, `codename`, `language`, `type`, `last_modified`, and `workflow_step`. For example, to retrieve only content items based on the _Article_ content type, use `system.type=article` as a query parameter. ### Filtering by element values To filter by [content element](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/ea9768d1-bd2f-4027-bb5e-5cd9c85ea360) values, you need to use a query parameter in the `elements.=` format. For example, to retrieve only content items whose number element named Price has a value of 16, use `elements.price=16` as a query parameter. ### Joining multiple query parameters You can join multiple query parameters using the `&` character. Queries with two or more filtering parameters are more restrictive because the individual query parameters are merged with a logical conjunction (AND). For example, the query `system.type=article&elements.category[contains]=nature` will return Article [content items tagged](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/01fa6fb2-b746-4bb9-92a9-95acd07c6a62) with the term _Nature_. ### Filtering operators You can use the following filtering operators with both the system properties and element values.
All operators are **case-sensitive**.
| **Operator** | **Description** | **Example** | **Use with** | | ------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------- | | `[eq]`(same as `=`) | Property value equals the specified value. | `system.type=article` `system.type[eq]=article` | Simple types | | `[neq]` | Property value does not equal the specified value. | `system.type[neq]=article` `system.workflow_step[neq]=archived` | Simple types | | `[empty]` | Property value is empty. | `elements.title[empty]` `elements.author[empty]` For [rich text](#section/Rich-text-element), use the equals operator, `elements.content[eq]=


`. | Simple types and arrays | | `[nempty]` | Property value is not empty. | `elements.title[nempty]` | Simple types and arrays | | `[lt]` | Property value is less than the specified value.More in [Comparing values](#tag/Filtering-content/comparing-values). | `system.last_modified[lt]=2019-03-01elements.price[lt]=10` | Simple types | | `[lte]` | Property value is less than or equal to the specified value.More in [Comparing values](#tag/Filtering-content/comparing-values). | `system.last_modified[lt]=2019-02-01elements.price[lte]=4` | Simple types | | `[gt]` | Property value is greater than the specified value.More in [Comparing values](#tag/Filtering-content/comparing-values). | `system.last_modified[gt]=2019-01-01elements.price[gt]=10` | Simple types | | `[gte]` | Property value is greater than or equal to the specified value.More in [Comparing values](#tag/Filtering-content/comparing-values). | `system.last_modified[gt]=2019-02-28elements.price[gt]=10` | Simple types | | `[range]` | Property value falls within the specified range of two values, both inclusive.More in [Comparing values](#tag/Filtering-content/comparing-values). | `system.last_modified[range]=2018-02-01,2018-03-31elements.price[range]=10.5,50` | Simple types | | `[in]` | Property value is in the specified list of values. | `system.type[in]=cafe,coffeeelements.price[in]=8.5,9,10.5` | Simple types | | `[nin]` | Property value is not in the specified list of values. | `system.type[nin]=home,page` | Simple types | | `[contains]` | Property with an array of values contains the specified value.The `[contains]` operator cannot be used on strings. | `elements.category[contains]=nature` `elements.custom[contains]=ABC` | Arrays | | `[any]` | Property with an array of values contains at least one value from the specified list of values. | `elements.category[any]=technology,nature` | Arrays | | `[all]` | Property with an array of values contains all of the specified values. | `elements.category[all]=technology,mobile` | Arrays | ### Arrays vs. simple types You can use the `[contains]`, `[any]`, and `[all]` filtering operators only on arrays. The content elements that support these operators are [custom elements](#section/Custom-element) (see limitations below), [linked items](#section/Linked-items-element), [multiple choice](#section/Multiple-choice-element), and [taxonomy](#section/Taxonomy-element). For custom elements, the `[contains]`, `[any]`, and `[all]` filters work only if the element's value is a stringified array of strings such as "["DE","US","UK"]". The `[contains]`, `[any]`, and `[all]` operators can NOT be used on asset elements. ### Comparing values The `[lt]`, `[lte]`, `[gt]`, `[gte]`, and `[range]` filtering operators work best with numbers. For example, you can retrieve products with price larger or equal to 15 by using `elements.price[gte]=15`.
**Filtering by date-time values** Properties that store dates are represented as strings. For example, this includes the `last_modified` system property and date & time content elements. If you use filtering operators on properties with string values, the Delivery API tries to perform a string comparison. For instance, you can retrieve content items modified during February and March by using a query such as `system.last_modified[range]=2020-02-01,2020-04-01`, specifying the start date within the range and end date outside the range.

tags.name: Linked content and components
tags.description:
With the Kontent.ai platform, you can [compose and structure](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/337e2e0a-fe9a-46cd-9176-2df0cedf1074) your content using rich text and linked items elements. * [Linked items elements](#section/Linked-items-element) are used to reference other content items. * [Rich text elements](#section/Rich-text-element) are used to compose your content with text, images, components, and content items. Components and content items are useful for inserting structured content into a specific point in the text.
**Components 101** [Rich text elements](#section/Rich-text-element) can contain components. * A component is a single-use content item. * It has the same structure as a content item. * Unlike a content item, a component only exists inside its rich text element. * It is based on a specific content type.
### Retrieve linked content When [retrieving items](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/4fafdf10-32c6-4020-a91a-cf1f835f8107) using the Delivery API, the contents of _all components and content items in the rich text and linked items elements_ are stored in the `modular_content` object property of the API response. When [enumerating the items](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/ac1819e7-aec6-4b26-a649-2a4efc377281) in your project using the Delivery API, the `modular_content` object property will contain only components, not content items used in linked items elements. The contents of `modular_content`, that is the individual components and content items, are not ordered. See [linked items](#section/Linked-items-element) and [rich text](#section/Rich-text-element) elements for details on how ordering is done within the elements. For historical reasons, the property is called "modular_content" instead of "linked_content". ### Linked content depth **Content items** can reference other content items using [linked items](#section/Linked-items-element) or [rich text](#section/Rich-text-element) elements. These linked items can reference other items recursively. By default, the API returns only one level of linked items. * To include more than one level of linked items in response, set the `depth` query parameter to 2 or more. * To exclude all linked items, set the `depth` query parameter to 0. When retrieving content, linked items cannot be [filtered](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/b6cf1d73-471a-4f1e-b0a9-f0e041e2d905). **Components** are not affected by the `depth` query parameter as they are an integral part of their rich text element. Components are always present in the API response. Components can be nested up to six levels deep.

tags.name: Projection
tags.description:
When [getting content items](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/4fafdf10-32c6-4020-a91a-cf1f835f8107) or [content types](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/f334b2b2-04e3-42bf-8812-c27cbac3ebc6), you can specify which elements to return by using the `elements` query parameter. * For items, the parameter applies to content items returned within both the `items` array and `modular_content` object property. * For types, the parameter applies to content types returned within the `types` array. ### Examples By using `elements=title` as a query parameter, the `elements` property in each content item will contain only the element with the codename `title`, or, if the item doesn't have an element with such codename, the `elements` property will be empty. For multiple elements, you can use a query parameter such as `elements=title,summary,related_articles` to retrieve only the elements with codenames `title`, `summary`, and `related_articles`.
**Excluding the system properties** Projection does not apply to the system properties. This means that you cannot omit the {~system~} object from the response using any query.

get.description:
Retrieve a list of content items from your project. By default, the API returns an unfiltered paginated list of content items ordered alphabetically by codename. The [response size](#section/Response-size) is limited to 2000 items. The `modular_content` object property will contain both components and linked items in the API response. See [Linked content and components](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/286dbb0e-f673-494f-abfd-3f39c7ec3446) for more details. If you need to export all content items from your project, we recommend using the [Enumerate content items](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/ac1819e7-aec6-4b26-a649-2a4efc377281) endpoint. You can change the order by specifying the `order` query parameter. You can customize pagination by specifying both the `skip` and `limit` query parameters. Note that the `limit` parameter affects only the `items` property, not `modular_content`.
**Get only the items you need** To retrieve specific content items, use the filtering parameters in your requests. For example, you can request items tagged with a taxonomy term, items of a specific type, or items modified in the past three days.

x-codeSamples.source:
curl --request GET \
  --url 'https://deliver.kontent.ai/<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>/items?system.type=article&limit=3' \
  --header 'content-type: application/json'

# Tip: Find more about Ruby SDKs at https://kontent.ai/learn/ruby
require 'delivery-sdk-ruby'

delivery_client = Kentico::Kontent::Delivery::DeliveryClient.new project_id: '<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>'
delivery_client.items('system.type'.eq('article'))
               .limit(3)
               .execute do |response|
                 items = response.items
               end

get.description:
Retrieve a specific content item by specifying its codename.

The [response size](#section/Response-size) is limited to 2000 items.

x-codeSamples.source:
curl --request GET \
  --url 'https://deliver.kontent.ai/<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>/items/my_article' \
  --header 'content-type: application/json'

# Tip: Find more about Ruby SDKs at https://kontent.ai/learn/ruby
require 'delivery-sdk-ruby'

delivery_client = Kentico::Kontent::Delivery::DeliveryClient.new project_id: '<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>'
delivery_client.item('my_article')
               .execute do |response|
                 item = response.item
               end

get.description:
Retrieve a dynamically paginated list of content items in your project. The items are ordered alphabetically by codename. If the response comes with the `X-Continuation` header, it means that there are more pages to retrieve. To get the next page of results, send the `X-Continuation` header with your request as you received it. This endpoint, unlike the [List content items](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/4fafdf10-32c6-4020-a91a-cf1f835f8107) endpoint, guarantees to enumerate all content items in the specified project. The `modular_content` object property will contain only components used in rich text elements in the API response. See [Linked content and components](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/286dbb0e-f673-494f-abfd-3f39c7ec3446) for more details. We recommend using this endpoint for warming up your app's cache (that is getting all content into the cache after the app starts) or for exporting the content of your project.
**Get only the items you need** To retrieve specific content items, use the filtering parameters in your requests. For example, you can request items tagged with a taxonomy term, items of a specific type, or items modified in the past three days.

x-codeSamples.source:
curl --request GET \
  --url 'https://deliver.kontent.ai/<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>/items-feed?system.type=article' \
  --header 'content-type: application/json'

get.description: Retrieve a content element defined in a specific content type. Both must be specified by their codenames.

x-codeSamples.source:
curl --request GET \
  --url 'https://deliver.kontent.ai/<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>/types/article/elements/title' \
  --header 'content-type: application/json'

# Tip: Find more about Ruby SDKs at https://kontent.ai/learn/ruby
require 'delivery-sdk-ruby'

delivery_client = Kentico::Kontent::Delivery::DeliveryClient.new project_id: '<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>'
delivery_client.element('article', 'title').execute do |response|
  ele = response.element
end

get.description: Retrieve a paginated list of content types in your project. By default, the API returns all content types ordered alphabetically by codename. You can customize pagination by specifying both the `skip` and `limit` query parameters.

x-codeSamples.source:
curl --request GET \
  --url 'https://deliver.kontent.ai/<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>/types?limit=3' \
  --header 'content-type: application/json'

# Tip: Find more about Ruby SDKs at https://kontent.ai/learn/ruby
require 'delivery-sdk-ruby'

delivery_client = Kentico::Kontent::Delivery::DeliveryClient.new project_id: '<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>'
delivery_client.types
               .limit(3)
               .execute do |response|
                 types = response.types
               end

curl --request GET \
  --url 'https://deliver.kontent.ai/<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>/types/article' \
  --header 'content-type: application/json'

# Tip: Find more about Ruby SDKs at https://kontent.ai/learn/ruby
require 'delivery-sdk-ruby'

delivery_client = Kentico::Kontent::Delivery::DeliveryClient.new project_id: '<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>'
delivery_client.type('article').execute do |response|
  type = response.type
end

get.description:
Retrieve a list of active languages from your project. By default, the API returns all languages ordered alphabetically by codename.
**Get only the languages you need** To retrieve specific languages, use the filtering parameters in your requests. For example, you can request two specific languages (using the `[in]` filter) or all but one language (using the `[neq]` filter).

x-codeSamples.source:
curl --request GET \
  --url 'https://deliver.kontent.ai/<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>/languages?limit=3' \
  --header 'content-type: application/json'

get.description: Retrieve a paginated list of taxonomy groups in your project. By default, the API returns all taxonomy groups ordered alphabetically by codename. You can customize pagination by specifying both the `skip` and `limit` query parameters.

x-codeSamples.source:
curl --request GET \
  --url 'https://deliver.kontent.ai/<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>/taxonomies?limit=3' \
  --header 'content-type: application/json'

# Tip: Find more about Ruby SDKs at https://kontent.ai/learn/ruby
require 'delivery-sdk-ruby'

delivery_client = Kentico::Kontent::Delivery::DeliveryClient.new project_id: '<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>'
delivery_client.taxonomies
               .limit(3)
               .execute do |response|
                 groups = response.taxonomies
               end

get.description: Retrieve a specific taxonomy group specified by codename.

x-codeSamples.source:
curl --request GET \
  --url 'https://deliver.kontent.ai/<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>/taxonomies/personas' \
  --header 'content-type: application/json'

# Tip: Find more about Ruby SDKs at https://kontent.ai/learn/ruby
require 'delivery-sdk-ruby'

delivery_client = Kentico::Kontent::Delivery::DeliveryClient.new project_id: '<YOUR_PROJECT_ID>'
delivery_client.taxonomy('personas').execute do |response|
  group = response.taxonomy
end

x_request_charge_a9674e2.description:
Specifies the number of content items returned in the response. This number covers both the items that directly match the specified query and the linked items returned in the response's `modular_content` property.

If the `X-Request-Charge` value of your requests exceeds 1000, we recommend applying more specific [filters](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/b6cf1d73-471a-4f1e-b0a9-f0e041e2d905) and checking if a lower value for the [`depth` parameter](#tag/Linked-content-and-components/linked-content-depth) works for you. Fewer items returned per response means shorter response times and better performance for your app.

a6be9b2b_718f_015a_fc50_f182e78f6884.title: modular_content
a6be9b2b_718f_015a_fc50_f182e78f6884.description:
A dictionary of [components and linked items](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/286dbb0e-f673-494f-abfd-3f39c7ec3446).

**Note**: The items and components are not in any particular order.

b1528ffb_e3c5_0159_c830_6621bf89b95d.title: modular_content
b1528ffb_e3c5_0159_c830_6621bf89b95d.description: The collection of related Content item objects (including component objects).

b4ffa411_c84a_01a7_74a7_88930d2b3ce2.title: options
b4ffa411_c84a_01a7_74a7_88930d2b3ce2.description: The list of multiple choice options available for the element. The order of the option objects in the array matches the order of the options in the UI.

b50e2244_4be5_01a1_eaf4_5dd42d15b023.title: value
b50e2244_4be5_01a1_eaf4_5dd42d15b023.description:
The element's value as an array of selected multiple choice options.
**Matching order** The order of the objects in the array matches the order of the options in the UI.

be845896_f1ab_0137_599a_baaaa039edf6.title: sitemap_locations
be845896_f1ab_0137_599a_baaaa039edf6.description: A list of sitemap locations that the content item is in.

c3a6e8a6_c1cf_01a6_2ffa_912a5f9746dd.title: message
c3a6e8a6_c1cf_01a6_2ffa_912a5f9746dd.description: The error message explaining what caused the error.
examples: The requested content item 'sample_item' was not found.

c48d826c_eee6_01c5_ab7f_a7a3e628b77b.title: renditions
c48d826c_eee6_01c5_ab7f_a7a3e628b77b.description: The image's rendition. Contains query parameters that need to be concatenated with the original asset's URL to apply image customization.

content_item.title: Content item
content_item.description: The content item with metadata and individual elements.

d36c0980_518d_0131_c827_7f981505b3f1.title: languages
d36c0980_518d_0131_c827_7f981505b3f1.description: Active languages available in the project.

d3aae50a_093d_01a8_ac85_79708b6fb958.title: name
d3aae50a_093d_01a8_ac85_79708b6fb958.description: The multiple choice option's display name.

d5219c26_c891_01bb_7dc2_152875475f99.title: last_modified
d5219c26_c891_01bb_7dc2_152875475f99.description: [ISO-8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO%5F8601 "International standard covering the exchange of date- and time-related data") formatted date-time of the last content type change.

da34bfc2_84d6_01a9_cc2d_50f0562dc893.title: value
da34bfc2_84d6_01a9_cc2d_50f0562dc893.description:
The linked pages as an array of item codenames.
**Matching order** The order of the codenames in the array matches the order of the content items in the UI. The content of these items can be found in the `modular_content` property (where the items are not ordered) of the API response when getting content items.

dc29b58e_29fd_0127_5700_7a2d4e1579ed.title: total_count
dc29b58e_29fd_0127_5700_7a2d4e1579ed.description:
The total number of objects matching the query.

The property is present only when [listing content items](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/4fafdf10-32c6-4020-a91a-cf1f835f8107) and using the `includeTotalCount` query parameter.

e443609c_b6bf_01e4_c22e_62d49bb01108.title: next_page
e443609c_b6bf_01e4_c22e_62d49bb01108.description: A URL to the next page of results.

e5d6559f_a8c0_014f_d978_5e36ab28c38c.title: query
e5d6559f_a8c0_014f_d978_5e36ab28c38c.description: Parameters set for the image rendition.

e7549085_1471_0157_8b36_056b3cd2eb0d.title: elements
e7549085_1471_0157_8b36_056b3cd2eb0d.description:
A list of [elements](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/ea9768d1-bd2f-4027-bb5e-5cd9c85ea360) that define the content type.
**Order may not match the order in UI** The order of the elements in the API response might not match their order in the UI.

ec13646a_1f2d_0144_0d58_2f0e7fa34819.title: language
ec13646a_1f2d_0144_0d58_2f0e7fa34819.description:
The codename of the language that the content is in.

For details on retrieving content in different languages, see [Getting localized content](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/bf83b286-9972-4e65-8db9-412ca17df944).

ec32f6e9_dce7_01e1_3f8b_e3030ecd640d.title: elements
ec32f6e9_dce7_01e1_3f8b_e3030ecd640d.description:
The item's [elements](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/ea9768d1-bd2f-4027-bb5e-5cd9c85ea360) with values for the specific language.
The order of the element objects might not match the content element order in the UI.

f638f48f_c686_01e4_262e_1d478ca901c2.title: limit
f638f48f_c686_01e4_262e_1d478ca901c2.description: The number of objects returned in the response. Reflects the value specified by the `limit` query parameter.

ff42d3fe_938a_0195_ef84_cba27d460536.title: skip
ff42d3fe_938a_0195_ef84_cba27d460536.description: The number of objects skipped from the response. Reflects the value specified by the `skip` query parameter.

n04369c15_ba95_01da_37da_1af4b10cce5b.title: type
n04369c15_ba95_01da_37da_1af4b10cce5b.description: The codename of the item's type.

n05eaa583_bd38_0159_ad2b_53425d57ad98.title: description
n05eaa583_bd38_0159_ad2b_53425d57ad98.description: The image's description in a specific language. Used for the alt attribute of an `` tag.
examples: Person sitting on a wooden pier

n08d30341_9167_0162_a788_351865251b8c.title: codename
n08d30341_9167_0162_a788_351865251b8c.description: Codename of the content type, generated from the content types's {~name~}.

n241fbd59_29cb_01eb_ff6f_a68beacb3469.title: error_code
n241fbd59_29cb_01eb_ff6f_a68beacb3469.description: The specific internal code for the type of error. Only useful for finding patterns among error requests.

n299aa40d_79a2_01b8_c5ef_7887bd6d2c0a.title: modular_content
n299aa40d_79a2_01b8_c5ef_7887bd6d2c0a.description:
Contains codenames of the [components and content items](#section/Rich-text-element/modular-content-components-and-items-in-rich-text) (not their contents) inserted into the rich text element. To get the contents of the inserted components and items, see how to [retrieve linked content](#tag/Linked-content-and-components/retrieve-linked-content).
**Two distinct** `modular_content` **properties** In the `modular_content` object property of the Delivery API response, you can find the contents of the linked content items and content components. In the rich text element's [modular_content array property](#section/Rich-text-element/modular-content-components-and-items-in-rich-text), you can find the codenames of the inserted content items and content components. The codenames in the rich text's `modular_content` array are grouped and ordered. First comes a group of item codenames followed by a group of component codenames. The order of codenames in each group matches that in the UI.

n2afde4b9_b613_019b_a4fc_6b1b91d161cb.title: name
n2afde4b9_b613_019b_a4fc_6b1b91d161cb.description: The multiple choice option's display name.

n2c51ca3f_cac8_018e_b336_8c8fbdb710e9.title: value
n2c51ca3f_cac8_018e_b336_8c8fbdb710e9.description:
The linked content items as an array of item codenames.
**Matching order** The order of the codenames in the array matches the order of the content items in the UI. The content of these items can be found in the `modular_content` property (where the items are not ordered) of the API response when getting content items.

n2cade906_1457_018e_7704_f42a707f3471.title: name
n2cade906_1457_018e_7704_f42a707f3471.description: Display name of the content type.

n2d9fceeb_6d2b_01e2_e624_b1f15542a80a.title: last_modified
n2d9fceeb_6d2b_01e2_e624_b1f15542a80a.description: [ISO-8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO%5F8601 "International standard covering the exchange of date- and time-related data") formatted date-time of the last change to the taxonomy group.

n34796a2c_0bb2_01fb_90bd_34fea348e4ac.title: specific_code
n34796a2c_0bb2_01fb_90bd_34fea348e4ac.description: Only useful for finding reasons behind failed requests in specific cases.

n34c86c6a_8adc_01bc_a366_3840459bbfa2.title: modular_content
n34c86c6a_8adc_01bc_a366_3840459bbfa2.description: A list of components used in rich text elements. See [Linked content and components](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/286dbb0e-f673-494f-abfd-3f39c7ec3446) for more details.

n3a3f3c37_ae28_01f5_e0a1_3e50b0bd6939.title: description
n3a3f3c37_ae28_01f5_e0a1_3e50b0bd6939.description: The asset's description for a specific language.
examples: Description of what the asset represents.

n3c1b7401_a647_0125_17d8_c45daf22c2ae.title: height
n3c1b7401_a647_0125_17d8_c45daf22c2ae.description: The image's height in pixels. Is `null` if the file is not an image.

n3f1e6092_2cfd_010e_c182_91f1ce1ae48f.title: value
n3f1e6092_2cfd_010e_c182_91f1ce1ae48f.description: The element's value can be either auto-generated from a text element or custom.

n42ba353d_3294_0138_d089_639a70903b1c.title: collection
n42ba353d_3294_0138_d089_639a70903b1c.description: The content item's [collection](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/f48c2c0b-755f-4d23-bd5d-7201fe5fff01) codename. For projects without collections enabled, the value is `default`.

n4888c598_5682_016d_6ee0_7b3fe27f0f30.title: value
n4888c598_5682_016d_6ee0_7b3fe27f0f30.description:
The element's value.
If the element does not contain any content, its value defaults to a single empty paragraph: `


`.
examples:
Basic formatted text: plain text, bold, italics, monospace, subscript, superscript.

Links: link to a content item, link to web URL, email link, link to asset.

Table

ABC
DEF
GHI

Image

Inserted content item

Component

n50d05ee1_1499_01d1_3601_d3428770372d.title: type
n50d05ee1_1499_01d1_3601_d3428770372d.description: The codename of the linked item's type.

n65511815_0234_0167_426d_936d42212e82.title: last_modified
n65511815_0234_0167_426d_936d42212e82.description:
[ISO-8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO%5F8601) formatted date and time of the last change to user-content of the content item.
Moving content items through workflow doesn't affect the `last_modified` value.

n66efeb9b_e806_0131_366d_cbbd1bd01d0a.title: value
n66efeb9b_e806_0131_366d_cbbd1bd01d0a.description: The element's value as a [ISO-8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO%5F8601) formatted string. Time in this element is displayed and interpreted as [UTC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coordinated%5FUniversal%5FTime "Coordinated Universal Time").

n6752d10e_4532_010a_61bb_7431b182601c.title: terms
n6752d10e_4532_010a_61bb_7431b182601c.description: A list of descendant taxonomy terms.

n6ce5d58b_48ca_013f_e09a_ddb613926947.title: id
n6ce5d58b_48ca_013f_e09a_ddb613926947.description: Unique internal identifier of the content type.

n6e35639e_97e5_017c_f0dd_1e7a64845015.title: taxonomy_group
n6e35639e_97e5_017c_f0dd_1e7a64845015.description: The codename of a specific taxonomy group that the element is using.

n6fd41e65_c66c_0146_98df_b6decc975691.title: links
n6fd41e65_c66c_0146_98df_b6decc975691.description: The hyperlinks in the text that point to content items. Each [link object](#section/Rich-text-element/links-single-object) contains the linked item's metadata.

n76613773_c3a6_0128_e64a_0dc7eab43fb4.title: value
n76613773_c3a6_0128_e64a_0dc7eab43fb4.description: The element's value as an array of selected taxonomy terms.

n7bc5c917_c2b2_0181_211b_f6bcb157efe8.title: codename
n7bc5c917_c2b2_0181_211b_f6bcb157efe8.description: The content item's codename. By default, generated from the item's display name.

n7ec6482b_faa3_01fc_c09d_f4c663f3e34a.title: count
n7ec6482b_faa3_01fc_c09d_f4c663f3e34a.description:
The number of retrieved objects.

If the `limit` and `skip` query parameters are not specified, the `count` property reflects the total number of objects in the project.

n7f17c88d_5421_01ac_123d_ac9be6c3ef00.title: workflow_step
n7f17c88d_5421_01ac_123d_ac9be6c3ef00.description:
The codename of the item's current workflow step. By default, generated from the workflow step's display name.

This property is not present for [components](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/286dbb0e-f673-494f-abfd-3f39c7ec3446).

n8a79a2ad_2122_01b1_4587_f83ac23192fd.title: value
n8a79a2ad_2122_01b1_4587_f83ac23192fd.description:
The assets inserted into the element. The asset objects are returned in the same order as shown in the UI.

Some of the properties are specific to images only: `width` and `height` represent the image's width and height dimensions and the `renditions` object contains details about [customized images](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/41122488-31c5-47ba-8444-05a3e87d10a0).

To display customized images on the website or an app, you first need to apply custom query parameters to the asset's original URL.

n8dcd81b5_d9f7_0109_c079_592bae454564.title: url_slug
n8dcd81b5_d9f7_0109_c079_592bae454564.description: The content item's URL slug. If the linked item doesn't use a URL slug element, the value of the {~url_slug~} property is an empty string.

n8e725eed_82c1_0148_b93b_07931e06d3c9.title: images
n8e725eed_82c1_0148_b93b_07931e06d3c9.description: The images inserted into the rich text element. Each [image object](#section/Rich-text-element/images-single-object) contains the image's metadata.

n92ef070f_a98a_0171_52eb_b644664978be.title: width
n92ef070f_a98a_0171_52eb_b644664978be.description: The image's width in pixels. Is `null` if the file is not an image.

n9e2e211c_634f_01bb_4d2c_989d09089414.title: taxonomy_group
n9e2e211c_634f_01bb_4d2c_989d09089414.description: The codename of a specific taxonomy group that the element is using.

pagination.title: Pagination
pagination.description: Information about the current page of results.

rich_text_image_object.title: Rich text image
rich_text_image_object.description: The name of the object represents an image id, such as {~14mio~}.

rich_text_link_object.title: Rich text link
rich_text_link_object.description: The name of the object represents a content item ID, such as {~f4b3fc05-e988-4dae-9ac1-a94aba566474~}.

untitled_content_item_4b71df4.title: rendition
untitled_content_item_4b71df4.description: The name of the object represents an image preset's codename. Currently, there's only one default preset that holds the [customized image](/tutorials/write-and-collaborate/create-content/work-with-media#a-customize-assets-for-a-better-fit).

depth.name: depth
depth.description:
Determines the level of nesting for content items that the API returns. By default, only the first level of linked items is returned, which is the same as setting {~depth=1~}. If you want to include more than one level of linked items in response, set the {~depth~} query parameter to {~2~} or more. If you need to exclude all linked items from the response, set the parameter to {~0~}.
Components are always present in response. See Linked content and components for more details.

element_codename.name: element_codename
element_codename.description:
Identifies the element by codename within the specified content type.
The element's codename has no relation to the type of the element.

elements.name: elements
elements.description:
Determines the elements to retrieve using a comma-separated list of element codenames. The {~elements~} query parameter applies to all content items within the response.

If not specified, all elements are retrieved. For more details, see [Projection](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/c4552a2f-142c-4415-b7aa-f2c5b165a84e).

example.Error: Invalid json. Content item codename: 'array_of_strings'. Content item name: 'Array of strings'

includetotalcount.name: includeTotalCount
includetotalcount.description:
Adds the information about the total number of content items matching your query. Only [the content filtering parameters](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/b6cf1d73-471a-4f1e-b0a9-f0e041e2d905) affect the resulting number. Other parameters in your query, such as `limit,` `skip`, or `order`, don't have an effect on it.

The number doesn't include linked items returned as part of the `modular_content` property. For the total number of items returned within the response, see the `X-Request-Charge` header.

When set to `true`, the pagination object returned in the API response contains an additional `total_count` property.

item_codename.name: item_codename
item_codename.description: Identifies the content item by codename.

language.name: language
language.description:
Determines which language variant of content items to return. By default, the API returns content in the default language.
If the requested content is not available in the specified language variant, the API follows the language fallbacks as configured in the Localization settings of your project.

limit_8cd54e2.name: limit
limit_8cd54e2.description:
Sets the number of objects to retrieve in a single request. If the `limit` parameter is not specified, the API returns all requested objects by default.

If `limit` is lower than the total number of objects matching your query, the `next_page` property in the `pagination` object of the API response will contain a URL to the next page of results.

The `limit` parameter affects only the number of items in the `items` property. It doesn't reduce the number of linked items in the `modular_content` property so you may hit the [response size limit](#section/Response-size) unexpectedly. You can set `depth=0` to avoid that.

order.name: order
order.description:
Determines the order of the retrieved objects. By default, the objects are sorted alphabetically by their codenames from A to Z in descending order.

To sort the requested objects in ascending order, set the `order` to `<property_name>[asc]` where `<property_name>` is the name of the object property you want to sort by. For example, `order=elements.title[asc]` or `order=system.codename[asc]`. Similarly, to sort in descending order, use the `[desc]` modifier. You can sort by any properties in the API response.

**Examples**

* Sort by date – `order=system.last_modified[desc]`
* Sort by a content item name – `order=system.name[asc]`
* Sort by an element value – `order=elements.<element_codename>[asc]`

project_id.name: project_id
project_id.description:
Identifies your project.

If you're using [environments](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/a814879f-64a2-4689-8a99-e4e98cdf60ba), the project ID becomes environment ID and specifies one of the project's environments.

skip.name: skip
skip.description:
Sets the number of objects to skip when requesting a list of objects. The `skip` parameter must be combined with the `limit` parameter to work. If `skip` is not specified, the API returns the first page of results.

You can combine the `limit` and `skip` parameters to specify page size and page number. For example, using `limit=10&skip=10` sets the page size to 10 and gets the second page of results.

taxonomy_group_codename.name: taxonomy_group_codename
taxonomy_group_codename.description: Identifies the taxonomy group by codename.

type_codename.name: type_codename
type_codename.description: Identifies the content type by codename.

x_continuation.name: X-Continuation
x_continuation.description:
Determines the next page of results to retrieve. By default, when the header is not set, the API returns the first page of results.

If there are more items to enumerate, the response will come with the {~X-Continuation~} header. To get the next page of results, use the {~X-Continuation~} header from the response in your request.

x_kc_wait_for_loading_new_content.name: X-KC-Wait-For-Loading-New-Content
x_kc_wait_for_loading_new_content.description:
Determines whether the API waits while fetching content, if the requested content has changed since the last request. This is useful when retrieving changed content in reaction to a [webhook](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/5b87f0a1-c271-449d-a9dc-04f995c89589) call.

By default, when the header is not set, the API serves stale content (if cached by the CDN) while it's fetching the new content to minimize wait time. To always fetch new content, set the header value to {~true~}.

x_request_charge.name: X-Request-Charge
x_request_charge.description:
Specifies the number of content items returned in the response. This number covers both the items that directly match the specified query and the linked items returned in the response's `modular_content` property.

If the `X-Request-Charge` value of your requests exceeds 1000, we recommend applying more specific [filters](https://learn-web-live-dev.azurewebsites.net/learn/link-to/id/b6cf1d73-471a-4f1e-b0a9-f0e041e2d905) and checking if a lower value for the [`depth` parameter](#tag/Linked-content-and-components/linked-content-depth) works for you. Fewer items returned per response means shorter response times and better performance for your app.

Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.

body_copy.name: Body
body_copy.value:
The 3 most important things when writing error messages

  1. Don’t abuse alerts for upselling or showing superfluous information. People will stop reading the messages that are actually important.
  2. Don’t just assume people know about the context of a message. They might toggle between apps and see your message days after it happened. Always include enough information for users to make sense of it.
  3. Use a friendly, non-technical, non-threatening tone of voice.

TL;DR Write actionable error messages that laypeople can understand.*

*Not sure if they do? Show them to a non-technical person and ask them to explain it back to you.

Read the full story on Medium.

Nullam odio ante, blandit ut posuere eu, eleifend vitae dui. Mauris sagittis, tortor et tempor eleifend, enim libero tempus velit, non hendrerit lacus sem eu lorem. Nulla cursus eu ante nec pulvinar.

Nulla in facilisis tortor, quis pretium tortor. Vivamus quis laoreet nisi, non egestas massa. Maecenas hendrerit massa leo. Maecenas convallis dui vitae lorem suscipit efficitur. Maecenas vel dignissim erat, fringilla luctus lorem. Vivamus hendrerit ante et accumsan fringilla. Nullam quis pellentesque erat.
